Package gov.nist.timestampingauthority

Class Clock

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.nist.timestampingauthority.Clock
  • public class Clock
extends java.lang.Object
    Class linked to an NTP server (clock) providing time. It allows for local storage of this clock by storing offset from local time and calculating the actual time using the offset. The clock is updated periodically to provide accurate time.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Clock

        public Clock​(java.net.InetAddress address,
             int port,
             long startDelayMs,
             int timeoutMs,
             long updateInterval)
        Create new clock by providing NTP server address and port.
        Parameters:
        address - NTP server address
        port - NTP server port
        startDelayMs - start synchronization after specified time
        timeoutMs - NTP server request timeout
        updateInterval - time interval between clock updates

    • Method Detail

      • getAddress

        public java.net.InetAddress getAddress()
        Get clock's NTP server address.
        Returns:
        server address

      • setAddress

        public void setAddress​(java.net.InetAddress address)
        Set clock's NTP server address. Will only be updated after the clock is restarted.
        Parameters:
        address - NTP server address

      • getPort

        public int getPort()
        Get clock's NTP server port.
        Returns:
        server port

      • setPort

        public void setPort​(int port)
        Set clock's NTP server port. Will only be updated after the clock is restarted.
        Parameters:
        port - NTP server port

      • getStartDelayMs

        public long getStartDelayMs()
        Get clock's start delay in ms.
        Returns:
        start delay in ms

      • setStartDelayMs

        public void setStartDelayMs​(long startDelayMs)
        Set clock's start delay in ms. Will only be updated after the clock is restarted.
        Parameters:
        startDelayMs - start delay in ms

      • getTimeoutMs

        public int getTimeoutMs()
        Get clock's timeout - time waiting for the time server to respond.
        Returns:
        clock's timeout in ms

      • setTimeoutMs

        public void setTimeoutMs​(int timeoutMs)
        Set clock's timeout - time waiting for the time server to respond. Will only be updated after the clock is restarted.
        Parameters:
        timeoutMs - clock's timeout in ms

      • getUpdateInterval

        public long getUpdateInterval()
        Get clock's update interval.
        Returns:
        update interval in ms

      • setUpdateInterval

        public void setUpdateInterval​(long updateInterval)
        Set clock's update interval. Will only be updated after the clock is restarted.
        Parameters:
        updateInterval - update interval in ms

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Tells if the clock is running, i.e. being updated regularly. This does not guarantee that the clock is accurate at the moment and can provide accurate time. Use isAccurate for that purpose.
        Returns:
        if the clock is running

      • isAccurate

        public boolean isAccurate()
        Tell whether the clock is accurate. The state can theoretically change between the calls to isAccurate() and getTime(), but should not happen because of long update intervals.
        Returns:
        false if the last clock update was unsuccessful or the clock was not updated yet

      • getOffset

        public long getOffset()
               throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Get clock's offset from the local time.
        Returns:
        offset in ms (add it to current local time to get correct time)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the clock is currently inaccurate

      • getTime

        public long getTime()
             throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Get time of the clock by adding offset to the local machine time. Non-blocking.
        Returns:
        time in ms
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the clock is currently inaccurate

      • start

        public void start()
        Start clock updates. From this point on every updateInterval milliseconds the clock gets updated, and if it doesn't, it is in inaccurate state and cannot give time.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stop clock update. After this method is called, isAccurate always returns false until the clock is started again.

      • updateTime

        private void updateTime()
        Update the offset of the clock by getting the accurate time from the server. TimeInfo class calculates the offset that needs to be used automatically.
